anatomical location body part affected: Femoral artery, popliteal artery, long saphenous vein, leg tissues
description: Femoral popliteal bypass is a surgical procedure used to treat peripheral artery disease (PAD) of the femoral and/or popliteal arteries. Blood is redirected through either a healthy blood vessel that has been transplanted or a man-made  graft material sewn above and below the narrowed or blocked artery. Typically, the grafts originate from the femoral artery in the groin and go to the popliteal artery either just above or below the knee. The procedure may be performed under epidural or general anesthesia.(3) It is the most commonly performed bypass surgery in the body and may be the procedure of choice in situations of severe ischemic disease and limb salvage(17)
indications: PAD in which medical management has not improved symptoms, or symptoms have worsened despite medical management(17)
Severe disability due to intermittent claudication (leg pain with exercise that subsides with rest) that interferes with lifestyle and/or ability to work(17)
Arterial flow to the femoral arteries must be good, with good femoral pulses in the groin

In light of advances in technologies for the less invasive endovascular interventions, many consider surgical bypass an option that should be reserved for patients who demonstrate contraindications to endovascular procedures or those for whom prior endovascular treatments have not been successful(10) –Results from an RCT conducted in the Netherlands suggested that heparin-bonded  endoluminal endograft outcomes at 30days post-procedure  were better than femoral popliteal bypass surgery outcomes and that 1-year  patency was similar(18) -Based on a study of 125 patients in which 38.1% and 32.2% were treated for critical limb ischemia in the endoluminal and surgical arms -Patients in the endoluminal endograft group showed signs of less morbidity, faster recovery, and improvement in QOL at 30 days post-procedure

ICD-10 codes.T81.719A: complication of unspecified artery following a procedure, not elsewhere classified, initial encounter
ICD-10 codes.T81.72XA: Complication of vein following a procedure, not elsewhere classified, initial encounter

I74.I74.3: embolism and thrombosis of arteries of lower extremities
I74.I74.4: embolism and thrombosis of arteries of extremities, unspecified

ICD-10 codes.I79.2: peripheral angiopathy in diseases classified elsewhere (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Typical procedure –The patient is supine with the leg abducted slightly and the knee flexed and supported. Incisions are made over femoral and popliteal artery and the area explored before bypass conducted. Options for bypass include autogenous in situ saphenous vein graft (described below), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) grafts or noncrimped velour graft, or composite graft(17) –The vessel used for the graft is normally the long saphenous vein. This vein runs up the medial side of the leg from the ankle to the groin in line with the incisions used to expose the artery. Sometimes the vein is removed through a small third incision at mid-thigh  level and sometimes the two main incisions are joined to make one long incision -In some cases, rather than being removed, the saphenous vein is left in place (in situ graft). In this procedure, the valves that prevent back flow of blood are removed  from inside the vein using a small scope. The vein is then attached to the femoral and popliteal arteries(3) -If the long saphenous vein is unusable, a vein from the other leg or from the arm may be used. If no vein is suitable, an artificial graft is used
Hospitalization times range from 2 to 10 days.(3) Sitting up and walking are generally allowed on the first postoperative day(3)
Postoperative symptoms include incisional pain and swelling

Patients also present with decreased endurance, lower extremity muscle atrophy, and decreased functional mobility following prolonged chronic activity-related  claudication due to PAD. Please see Clinical Review…Peripheral Artery Disease (P AD) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708878 for more information on this condition –Risk factors for PAD include cigarette smoking, diabetes mellitus, elevated fibrinogen level, low HDL cholesterol, elevated systolic blood pressure, and age > 75 years Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications
contraindications precautions to test: Assess for signs/symptoms of DVT and immediately refer back to physician or to emergency services if present
Consult physician if nonhealing wounds are present

Assess peripheral pulses bilaterally –A patient referred to physical therapy for plantar fasciitis was found instead to have significant PAD when peripheral pulses were considered alongside presentation and family history(19)
Screen patient for other conditions that may limit exercise tolerance, such as foot pathology, arthritis, chest pain, and shortness of breath
Stop the exam if patient complains of chest pain, shortness of breath, abnormal fatigue, or dizziness

overall contraindications precautions: Follow surgeon’s instructions regarding participation in strenuous activities, return to work, and resumption of normal activity Patients are usually advised to rest and not exert themselves for at least 2 to 6 weeks
The surgical site should be kept clean and dry. Follow surgeon’s instructions pertaining to bathing

Notify physician in the event of any of the following: Fever and/or chills Increased pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding or other drainage from the leg Incision coolness Numbness and/or tingling or other changes in the affected extremity Chest pain/pressure, nausea and/or vomiting, profuse sweating, dizziness, and/or fainting
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Assess for signs/symptoms of DVT and immediately refer back to physician or to emergency services if present
Consult physician if nonhealing wounds are present

Assess peripheral pulses bilaterally –A patient referred to physical therapy for plantar fasciitis was found instead to have significant PAD when peripheral pulses were considered alongside presentation and family history(19)
Screen patient for other conditions that may limit exercise tolerance, such as foot pathology, arthritis, chest pain, and shortness of breath
Stop the exam if patient complains of chest pain, shortness of breath, abnormal fatigue, or dizziness

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When was the date of surgery? -Describe the procedure performed. Was a vein graft or man-made  graft used? -Have there been any complications? Was postoperative course as expected? -What was the reason for the surgery? What were the patient’s chief complaints prior to the surgery? How long had patient been experiencing symptoms prior to surgery? How did the symptoms prior to surgery limit the patient’s physical activity?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Conservative treatment may involve lifestyle modification advice (e.g., smoking cessation), a walking program, elastic compression garments, and medical management of risk factors (e.g., heart disease, cerebrovascular disease) Minimally invasive treatments (i.e., endovascular treatments) Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of the femoral arteries(5) Endovascular cryoplasty(10) Excisional atherectomy(10) Angioplasty with or without stenting Endografts(18) Bypass surgery is primarily recommended for limb-threatening  symptoms
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Patients are commonly prescribed aspirin or warfarin to reduce the risk of the bypass getting blocked. This may be continued indefinitely Pain medications are usually given intravenously or by epidural for the first few postoperative days, followed by orally as needed Antibiotics may be given to prevent infection Patients undergoing this procedure are commonly on lipid-lowering  and antihypertensive medications
diagnostic tests completed: Preoperative tests typically include the following:
Angiography to image the blocked artery
Ultrasound scan of the blocked artery
Ultrasound assessment of the vein to be used for the graft
Intraoperative tests may include the following:
Doppler studies to confirm adequate blood flow to the graft
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), what they are used for, and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Was the patient given an exercise program preoperatively? What education has the patient been provided regarding the condition and the surgery?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Patients typically have a history of intermittent claudication brought on by activity. Document preoperative activity level (e.g., distance walked) before claudication onset. Compare to postoperative as applicable
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Note sites of incisional pain and swelling. Document if there is any claudication pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night if applicable
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia). Patients with PAD affecting femoral arteries often also have PAD elsewhere, which may be symptomatic
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient need supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation? Any respiratory symptoms while walking? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__/No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has patient had previous surgery for PAD? Describe location and outcome
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension are commonly associated with PAD Risk for graft infection is higher in patients with obesity, cancer, diabetes, or other immunocompromised states(13)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) Diabetes medication is common in the population that undergoes this procedure
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work? Does the patient participate in recreational or leisure activities? How much physical activity does the patient typically perform daily as compared to prior to onset of PAD and prior to surgery?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Is the patient currently using any assistive or adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: –Girth measurements should be made to assess for edema. Leg swelling is normal postoperatively and may last 2–3months(3) –Document height and weight and calculate BMI -Obesity has been reported to predict surgical site infections after lower extremity bypass regardless of bypass origin, and mortality risk is increased in morbidly obese patients(6)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for equipment. Ambulatory assistive devices may be needed temporarily during the postoperative period to facilitate early mobilization. If patient is continuing to use assistive device, assess use and condition
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance in sitting and standing, statically and dynamically. The Berg Balance Scale can be used as an objective measure to assess balance
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Monitor vital signs, including heart rate (HR), respiration rate (RR), blood pressure, and oxygen saturation
Postoperative assessment should include auscultation for air entry, complete and effective aeration of each lung field, and adventitious sounds that may indicate pulmonary disease
Assess deep breathing and coughing ability
The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) can be used to assess endurance
The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used to assess exercise intensity
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses bilaterallyComplete a motor and sensory scan to rule out lower extremity peripheral nerve injury, a rare complicationIf indicated, assess biomechanics during activities, noting posture and safetyAssess as indicated. The FIM or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test can be used for standardized measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait, noting asymmetry and deviations. Assess gait speed using 10-meter  walk test (10MWT); assess safety with the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess lower extremity muscle strength using manual muscle testing (MMT)
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect incision for any redness, swelling, or drainage
Palpate skin temperature of lower extremities bilaterally
Note color of lower extremities bilaterally
Document any nonhealing lower extremity ulcers or wounds
Assess for signs and symptoms of DVT
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess lower extremity ROM bilaterallyBarthel Index or FIM can be used to assess independence in daily
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess light touch, deep pressure, proprioception, two-point  discrimination, and temperature
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –PADQOL questionnaire(15) –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS)

contraindications precautions: Patients should not resume driving for 46 weeks or until pain free
Typically, patients are advised to walk every day and to slowly increase distance
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young and the very old
Persons with an aversion to cold
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients should be advised to keep the leg elevated when sitting and to place a pillow under the leg when sleeping
Follow physician’s instructions about increasing activity

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Postoperative femoral popliteal bypass surgery with potential for incisional pain, swelling, impaired walking, decreased endurance, and reduced lower extremity strength; potential functional deficits in posture, balance, and gait mechanics; potential fall risk; potential for additional cardiovascular risk factors
prognosis: These are definitions for endovascular procedures that are related to prognosis. This is related to the durability of interventions and clinicians use different terms to describe sustained treatment success(20) –Primary patency—most important: Norestenosis (i.e., abnormal narrowing of artery or valve after surgery) of the target lesion during follow-up –Primary assisted patency: symptomatic restenosis with patency of the target lesion following bypass at the target vessel site –Secondary patency:patency of the target lesion after treatment of a (re)occlusion of the index lesion

Authors of a 2019 systematic review concluded that vein grafts were better than prosthetic grafts in above-knee  femoral popliteal bypasses(21) –Included were eight RCTs reporting 1,271 grafts (608 saphenous vein and 663 prosthetic) –Vein grafts were found to have better primary patency, primary assisted patency, secondary patency, and less need for reintervention –There were no differences between vein and prosthetic grafts with respect to 30-day  mortality, 30-day  morbidity, major amputation, or overall survival

When a vein is used, the bypass is reported to remain open for at least 5 years after surgery in about 66% of patients. When a man-made  graft is used, the bypass remains open in 33–50%  of patients 5 years after surgery(1)
Femoral popliteal bypass surgery is one of the most common surgical procedures used for those experiencing claudication of the superficial femoral and proximal popliteal arteries(8)
Success rates are greater when the underlying causes of atherosclerosis are monitored and managed effectively

Synthetic peripheral bypass vascular grafts carry a high risk of morbidity. The complication rate (including hemorrhage, limb ischemia, amputation, revision, and infection) has been reported to be as high as 50%(13)
Para-anastomotic  aneurysm is a rare but life-threatening  consequence of vascular reconstruction that can result in erosion of adjacent tissues, embolization, and rupture of the aneurysmal sac(16)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Nutritionist for weight loss, smoking cessation program, wound care specialist, cardiologist, cardiac rehabilitation program as indicated, occupational therapist for ADLs, social work for equipment and placement needs
other considerations: Femoral popliteal bypass using endoscopic vein harvest is reported to result in lower postoperative morbidity and shorter lengths of hospital stay than open vein harvest(7) –Based on a retrospective analysis conducted in the United States of 27 patients who had endoscopic vein harvest –Patency rates were satisfactory and were maintained at 70-month  follow-up

Endovascular interventions are preferred by patients, can be repeated, and preserve the option of bypass surgery.(9) Comparisons of femoral popliteal bypass and less invasive techniques have reported: –Similar primary patency at 24-month  follow-up  of percutaneous self-expanding  stent when compared with conventional femoral popliteal bypass grafting with synthetic conduit(11) –Angioplasty with primary stenting of the superficial femoral artery or popliteal artery provides durable results in patients with TASC A and/or B lesions but is less effective in patients with TASC C or D lesions(2) -TASC A and B are defined as lesions that have good to excellent results with endovascular interventions. TASC C lesions are those for which surgical management provides superior long-term  results. TASC D lesions should be treated by open surgery –Frequency of stent fracture after interventions for long-segment  disease is of concern.(9) The best results are obtained when treating focal stenoses(9) –Late outcomes of balloon angioplasty and angioplasty with selective stenting for superficial femoral popliteal disease are equivalent(14) -The lack of improved clinical outcomes and significantly higher cost of stenting supports selective use of stenting –One-year  patency was similar in an RCT comparing femoral popliteal bypass and heparin-bonded  expanded PTFE endografts(18)

maintenance or prevention: Exercise programs and lifestyle changes should be attempted before considering bypass surgery, because these changes can extend life, whereas bypass surgery alone will not Exercise programs and lifestyle changes can increase the capacity for pain-free  walking without the risks of bypass surgery Patients may be swayed by the fact that surgery is faster than lifestyle changes for improving walking. It may take up to 1 year to realize the benefits from an exercise program Quitting smoking is one of the most important lifestyle changes for prevention of PAD

Information from Vascular Cures,a U.S. nonprofit association representing patients with vascular disorders,
Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on June 14, 2019
